content.question:
<math alttext="C u B r solid is equilibrium with C u with positive 1 charge aqueous plus B r with negative 1 charge aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuBr(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>⇄</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mtext>Cu</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
Shown above is the chemical equation for the dissolution of the slightly soluble salt <math alttext="C u B r solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuBr</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. Its <math alttext="K sub s p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> value in pure water was experimentally determined. <math alttext="C u B r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuBr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> was found to be much less soluble in a <math alttext="0.001 molar N a B r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.001</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>NaBr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> solution than in pure water. Which of the following correctly explains the decrease in solubility of <math alttext="C u B r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuBr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in <math alttext="0.001 molar N a B r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.001</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi><mtext> NaBr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>?

choices.label: The concentration of water is much less in the <math alttext="N a B r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaBr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> solution than in pure water, reducing the rate of dissolution of the salt.

The presence of <math alttext="N a with positive 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Na</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions in the solution inhibits the dissolution of salts.

The presence of additional <math alttext="B r with negative 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> already in the solution decreases the value of the <math alttext="K sub s p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="C u B r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuBr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, causing the solubility to decrease.

The presence of additional <math alttext="B r with negative 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions already in the solution means equilibrium will be reached when much less <math alttext="C u B r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuBr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> has dissolved.

content.answer: The presence of additional <math alttext="B r with negative 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions already in the solution means equilibrium will be reached when much less <math alttext="C u B r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CuBr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> has dissolved.

skill.text: 2.F: Explain how modifications to an experimental procedure will alter results.
